docs.title: Goals
docs.text: This plugin aims to make it possible to process large amounts of video data with low-spec hardware, specifically to quantify and analyze zebrafish kinetic activity.

docs.title: Features
docs.text: Using Fiji as its backbone, it inherits its multi-platform capabilities. Bytedeco's JavaCPP Presets for FFmpeg and OpenCV makes the low-RAM processing possible, here implemented with the necessary graphical interfaces and integrations with ImageJ's codebase.

docs.title: About Us
docs.text:
This project was developed at the Laboratório de Diferenciação Muscular e Citoesqueleto (Instituto de ciências biomédicas, UFRJ).

Authors: Murilo Nespolo Spineli, Paloma Vieira, Claudia Mermelstein and Manoel Luis Costa.

Please report any questions to manoelluiscosta@ufrj.br

docs.title: Extract Frequency Data
docs.text:
Extracts X and Y positional data from the selected XML file and allows the user to visualize the results in a graphical plot.

Results Table Output

Exporting data from imageJ's result tables to the default CSV option can led to problems related to decimal case separators. If you found this error, we recommend the usage of Excel Functions, a plugin that allows trouble-free data exports to xlsx format.

docs.title: XML File
docs.text:
Tracking Required

Note that this function depends on the previous use of Trackmate to gather data about movement frequency, so files without them will get rejected.

Two possible files can be used here:

  1. Trackmate's whole save file
  2. Output of trackmate's Export tracks to XML file export action.

docs.title: Source Video
docs.text: The source video used for tracking. Ideally not the processed one, so you can set the ROIs better.

docs.title: Fix Missing Spots
docs.text:
When tracking with Trackmate, not all frames in a video will have spots. That's because your target might not be visible in those frames. It's usually not moving as well. An uneven number of frames will create an unreliable score overall. This option fixes the missing spots by using an available adjacent spot and copying its coordinates.

There's no prejudice in setting this to True if you have a perfect tracking, with spots in all frames.

If you have only spots and no tracks, this feature won't work in this mode. It is not significant to mean out the positions of scores on each frame; thus, this checkbox gets deactivated if this is the case.

docs.title: Display Plots
docs.text: • Line Chart: Composed chart to display displacement over time.

docs.title: Quantify Heatmap
docs.text:
Quantify the area of a binary heatmap to analyze the animal percentage traveled area. It counts the black pixels from a given binary image.

Results Table Output

Exporting data from imageJ's result tables to the default CSV option can led to problems related to decimal case separators. If you found this error, we recommend the usage of Excel Functions, a plugin that allows trouble-free data exports to xlsx format.

docs.title: Input Binary Heatmap Image
docs.text:
The binary heatmap image to be processed. Ideally, generated with Binary Heatmap Image.

Image Input

This plugin also accepts the current open image as input. In that case, leave this field blank and ensure you have the image opened in Fiji before running the plugin.

docs.title: Display plots
docs.text: • Bar Chart: Simple chart to represent area percentage.

docs.title: Create sequential ROIs
docs.text: Opens the Create sequential ROIs plugin window.

docs.title: Calculate Score Gradient
docs.text:
From user-defined min and max values, calculates a score (0-10) of each spot from Trackmate.

Results Table Output

Exporting data from imageJ's result tables to the default CSV option can led to problems related to decimal case separators. If you found this error, we recommend the usage of Excel Functions, a plugin that allows trouble-free data exports to xlsx format.

docs.title: XML File
docs.text:
Two possible files can be used here:

  1. Trackmate's whole save file
    • Ideal option overall.
    • Mandatory if you only have spots and no tracks. In this case, a mean score of every spot on each frame will be calculated.
    • If there are any tracks, all spots outside them will get filtered out.
  2. Output of trackmate's Export tracks to XML file export action.
    • Only spots in tracks get saved in this file, so only them will be considered.

docs.title: Source Video
docs.text: The source video used for tracking. Ideally not the processed one, so you can set the ROIs better.

docs.title: Fix Missing Spots
docs.text:
When tracking with Trackmate, not all frames in a video will have spots. That's because your target might not be visible in those frames. It's usually not moving as well. An uneven number of frames will create an unreliable score overall. This option fixes the missing spots by using an available adjacent spot and copying its coordinates.

There's no prejudice in setting this to True if you have a perfect tracking, with spots in all frames.

docs.title: Display Plots
docs.text:
• Box Chart: The starting edge of the box corresponds to the 1st Quartile (Q1, 25th percentile), and the ending edge corresponds to the 3rd Quartile (Q3, 75th percentile). The line crossing through the interior of the box indicates the Median (Q2). The whiskers reach the lowest and highest data points that are within 1.5 times the IQR from the box edges.

  • Dial Chart: Dial is set to the median score value. (If you have multiple tracks, montage of all track's dials is created)

docs.title: Open Frame
docs.text: Opens the first frame of the video as a preview. Can be used to set the ROI in functions that require it. Ignores the file's EXIF rotation data.

docs.title: Load Min/Max from XML
docs.text: Gathers and displays the min and max position values from the current XML. It is required to click this button to check for calibration issues.

docs.title: Change Max Score
docs.text: Allows the user to change the max value by clicking on the preview image.

docs.title: Change Min Score
docs.text: Allows the user to change the min value by clicking on the preview image.

docs.title: Stop
docs.text: Stop changing max and min values.

docs.title: Calculate Score Sectors
docs.text:
Represents the total number of identified spots within the selected ROIs. This function allows the user to calculate the percentage of spots located in a given area, such as the maze arms. The number and area of the ROIs are defined by the user, as long as at least one ROI is selected.

Results Table Output

Exporting data from imageJ's result tables to the default CSV option can led to problems related to decimal case separators. If you found this error, we recommend the usage of Excel Functions, a plugin that allows trouble-free data exports to xlsx format.

docs.title: XML File
docs.text:
Two possible files can be used here:

  1. Trackmate's whole save file
    • Ideal option overall.
    • Mandatory if you only have spots and no tracks. In this case, spots will be considered as-is, without fixing missing spots.
    • If there are any tracks, all spots outside them will get filtered out.
  2. Output of trackmate's Export tracks to XML file export action.
    • Only spots in tracks get saved in this file, so only them will be considered.

docs.title: Source Video
docs.text: The source video used for tracking. Ideally not the processed one, so you can set the ROIs better.

docs.title: Fix Missing Spots
docs.text:
When tracking with Trackmate, not all frames in a video will have spots. That's because your target might not be visible in those frames. It's usually not moving as well. An uneven number of frames will create an unreliable score overall. This option fixes the missing spots by using an available adjacent spot and copying its coordinates.

There's no prejudice in setting this to True if you have a perfect tracking, with spots in all frames.

If you have only spots and no tracks, this feature won't work in this mode. It is not significant to mean out the positions of scores on each frame.

docs.title: Display Plots
docs.text: • Pie Chart: Simple chart to represent spot prevalence in different areas by percentage.

docs.title: Thigmotaxis
docs.text:
Analyzes the percentage of distance and time spent by the larvae in the inner and outer regions of the plate, defined by the user.

A pre-defined region of interest (ROI) is required, either drawn on the preview frame (opened by clicking the Open Frame button) or by having it in the ROI Manager.

Results Table Output

Exporting data from imageJ's result tables to the default CSV option can led to problems related to decimal case separators. If you found this error, we recommend the usage of Excel Functions, a plugin that allows trouble-free data exports to xlsx format.

docs.title: XML File
docs.text:
Tracking Required

Note that this function depends on the previous use of Trackmate to gather data about movement distance, so files without them will not get those results.

Two possible files can be used here:

  1. Trackmate's whole save file
  2. Output of trackmate's Export tracks to XML file export action.

docs.title: Source Video
docs.text: The source video used for tracking. Ideally not the processed one, so you can set the ROIs better.

docs.title: Area Percentage
docs.text: Specifies the percentage of the ROI used to calculate the Thigmotaxis. Note this is a percentage of area, not of dimensions.

docs.title: Fix Missing Spots
docs.text:
When tracking with Trackmate, not all frames in a video will have spots. That's because your target might not be visible in those frames. It's usually not moving as well. An uneven number of frames will create an unreliable score overall. This option fixes the missing spots by using an available adjacent spot and copying its coordinates.

There's no prejudice in setting this to True if you have a perfect tracking, with spots in all frames.

If you have only spots and no tracks, this feature won't work in this mode. It is not significant to mean out the positions of scores on each frame.

docs.title: Display Plots
docs.text: • Stacked Bar Chart: Simple chart to represent time and distance relative percentages.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
For Windows Users

If Fiji is installed in an admin-owned folder (such as C:\Program Files\), you need to open Fiji with administrator privileges every time on the next steps!

docs.title: Automatic Installation (Fiji)
docs.text:
1. Run Fiji → Help → Update…
  2. Click the Manage update sites button
  3. In the new popup window search for the site name Animove and activate the checkbox
  4. Press the Close button
  5. Finally, press the Apply changes button and restart Fiji
  6. The plugin will appear in Fiji's menu bar.
  7. Installing dependencies (this is only done once, not every update)
    • Run Animove → Tools → Check Dependencies
    • Follow the instructions, you'll need to restart Fiji multiple times

docs.title: Automatic Updating
docs.text: The plugin updates via the Update Manager built into Fiji. A search for updates can be triggered by running Fiji → Help → Update…

docs.title: Manual Installation (Legacy ImageJ)
docs.text:
1. Download the Plugin:

    • The latest version of the plugin is a .jar file located in the target/directory of this project.

  2. Locate Your Fiji Installation:

    • Find where you have Fiji installed on your computer. This is often in your Documents or Program Files folder.

  3. Copy the .jar File:

    • Copy the .jar file you downloaded into the plugins folder inside your Fiji installation directory (Fiji.app/plugins/).

    • The final file path should look something like this:

      • C:\Users\YourUserName\Documents\Fiji.app\plugins\Animove-0.0.1.jar
      • or C:\Program Files\Fiji.app\plugins\Animove-0.0.2.jar

  4. Restart Fiji: Close and reopen Fiji to continue the installation.

  5. Installing dependencies (this is only done once, not every update)

    • Run Animove → Tools → Check Dependencies
    • Follow the instructions, you'll need to restart Fiji multiple times

docs.title: Manual Updating
docs.text: Updates are manual and should be done like a re-install. Remember to replace the old .jar file with the new one, not leaving old versions.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Animove is displayed in the upper-right area of Fiji's menu bar.

File requirements are available in each function description.

docs.title: Testing files
docs.text:
Testing video files are available. Notably:

  • Adults
    • Gutter/Track (short and long versions)
    • Plus Maze
    • Tank (sideways recording)
    • Tracking data
  • Larvae
    • Six-well plate (short and long versions)

These may be used to experiment on the plugin's capabilities or simply to get used to the workflows.

The data made available is property of the authors and should not be distributed in any way. Usage outside the plugin's scope is not allowed.

docs.title: Grayscale Converting Disclaimer
docs.text:
All RGB videos get converted to grayscale for processing. All image channels will get merged into a single one.

The conversion is handled by OpenCV, using the proportions: 0.114 * B + 0.587 * G + 0.229 * R

These are the same proportions ImageJ uses in AVI_Reader and ColorProcessor conversions.

docs.title: Adults Tracking
docs.text:
Pre-process the input video to make it suitable for Trackmate analysis. These steps include image inversion, as Trackmate algorithm recognizes white spots in a dark background. It uses Top-Hat processing to subtract the background and adjusts brightness and contrast.

A TrackMate tutorial can be found here.

FPS reduction

We found 10 fps to be suitable to track adult fish movement. It's possible to change the framerate using this plugin's FFmpeg tool

docs.title: Input Video
docs.text: Any videos supported by ffmpeg. This includes most video formats in existence. Notably, one exclusion: AVI videos saved from ImageJ with compression set to "None" (codec rawvideo) will not work.

docs.title: Output File
docs.text: The path to save the operation's output.

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text: The user can choose between AVI, TIFF or MP4.

docs.title: Start and End frame
docs.text:
Specify the frame number to begin and end the processing.

The selection is inclusive, meaning both the start and end frames will be processed.

Frame numbers are one-indexed (the first frame has a frame number equal to 1).

To process the video all the way to its final frame, enter 0 in the 'End frame' field.

docs.title: Preview
docs.text: Shows a preview of the function, using the first 10 frames ahead of the Start frame set by the user.

docs.title: Binary Heatmap Image
docs.text:
Generates a binary heatmap image. Processing steps:

  • Heatmap Generation Iterates through the video frames, performing an Otsu automatic threshold to binarize the frames, then aggregates them using a minimum Z-Projection.

  • Background Reference Creation: Performs a second iteration over the frames to calculate the Average Z-projection of the raw footage.

  • Final Composition: Binarizes and inverts the generated average image (using the same method), then adds it mathematically to the binary heatmap to produce the final result.

docs.title: Input Video
docs.text: Any videos supported by ffmpeg. This includes most video formats in existence. Notably, one exclusion: AVI videos saved from ImageJ with compression set to "None" (codec rawvideo) will not work.

docs.title: Open Frame
docs.text: Opens the first frame of the video as a preview. Can be used to set the ROI in functions that require it. Ignores the file's EXIF rotation data.

docs.title: Output Image
docs.text: The path to save the operation's image output. Tiff is the recommended format, although all formats supported by OpenCV imwrite are supported.

docs.title: Save Output
docs.text: Choose whether to save the output to the specified output path. If left unchecked, only displays the output.

docs.title: Start and End frame
docs.text:
Specify the frame number to begin and end the processing.

The selection is inclusive, meaning both the start and end frames will be processed.

Frame numbers are one-indexed (the first frame has a frame number equal to 1).

To process the video all the way to its final frame, enter 0 in the 'End frame' field.

docs.title: Preview
docs.text: Shows a preview of the function, using the first 10 frames ahead of the Start frame set by the user.

docs.title: Sum Heatmap Images
docs.text:
Generates an image using pixelwise addition of the selected frames. Processing steps:

  • Background Reference Creation: Performs an iteration over the frames to calculate the Average Z-projection of the raw footage.

  • Background Subtraction: Starts a second iteration over the frames. In this step, subtracts the generated average background from each frame.

  • Brightness Adjust: Increases the overall brightness.

  • Frame Sum: Ending the second frame iteration, this operation sums all pixel values into a single 32-bit frame.

  • Final Composition: A simple B&C adjust is applied, stretching the histogram to its boundaries. After that, the selected Lookup table (LUT) is applied.

docs.title: Input Video
docs.text: Any videos supported by ffmpeg. This includes most video formats in existence. Notably, one exclusion: AVI videos saved from ImageJ with compression set to "None" (codec rawvideo) will not work.

docs.title: Output Folder
docs.text: Where output images will be saved with .tif format.

docs.title: Lookup Table
docs.text: The LUTs available are the ImageJ's built-in ones (found at Image → Lookup Tables).

docs.title: Intervals
docs.text:
The checkboxes either activate or deactivate the relative interval.

Frame numbers should be presented as initialFrame-endFrame, both being inclusive, like ImageJ's built-in Image → Duplicate feature.

An empty interval field results in a skipped interval, while a malformed one (without a - separator) throws an error.

docs.title: Sum Heatmap Video
docs.text:
Generates a video file using pixelwise addition of the selected frames. Processing steps are the same as Sum Heatmap Images.

Each frame is then concatenated into a single video.

docs.title: Input Video
docs.text: Any videos supported by ffmpeg. This includes most video formats in existence. Notably, one exclusion: AVI videos saved from ImageJ with compression set to "None" (codec rawvideo) will not work.

docs.title: Output File
docs.text: The path to save the operation's output.

docs.title: Lookup Table
docs.text: The LUTs available are the ImageJ's built-in ones (found at Image → Lookup Tables). Leave as "Don't change" for RGB images if Convert to Grayscale is not checked.

docs.title: Start and End frame
docs.text:
Specify the frame number to begin and end the processing.

The selection is inclusive, meaning both the start and end frames will be processed.

Frame numbers are one-indexed (the first frame has a frame number equal to 1).

To process the video all the way to its final frame, enter 0 in the 'End frame' field.

docs.title: Preview
docs.text: Shows a preview of the function, using the first 10 frames ahead of the Start frame set by the user.

docs.title: Larvae Tracking
docs.text:
Pre-process the input video to make it suitable for Trackmate analysis. These steps include frames duplication and inversion, as Trackmate algorithm recognizes white spots in a dark background. Background subtraction trough average subtraction is also performed.

A TrackMate tutorial can be found here.

FPS reduction

We found 20 fps to be suitable to track larvae fish movement. It's possible to change the framerate using this plugin's FFmpeg tool

docs.title: Input Video
docs.text: Any videos supported by ffmpeg. This includes most video formats in existence. Notably, one exclusion: AVI videos saved from ImageJ with compression set to "None" (codec rawvideo) will not work.

docs.title: Output File
docs.text: The path to save the operation's output.

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text: The user can choose between AVI, TIFF or MP4.

docs.title: Start and End frame
docs.text:
Specify the frame number to begin and end the processing.

The selection is inclusive, meaning both the start and end frames will be processed.

Frame numbers are one-indexed (the first frame has a frame number equal to 1).

To process the video all the way to its final frame, enter 0 in the 'End frame' field.

docs.title: Preview
docs.text: Shows a preview of the function, using the first 10 frames ahead of the Start frame set by the user.

docs.title: Save Output
docs.text: Choose whether to save the output to the specified output path. If left unchecked, only displays the output.

docs.title: Excel functions
docs.text:
Results Table Output

Exporting data from imageJ's result tables to the default CSV option can led to problems related to decimal case separators. If you found this error, we recommend the usage of Excel Functions, a plugin that allows trouble-free data exports to xlsx format.

docs.title: Input Video
docs.text: Any videos supported by ffmpeg. This includes most video formats in existence. Notably, one exclusion: AVI videos saved from ImageJ with compression set to "None" (codec rawvideo) will not work.

docs.title: Invert before operation
docs.text: Invert each frame before performing the operation. Done as a bitwise NOT operation.

docs.title: Open Frame
docs.text: Opens the first frame of the video as a preview. Can be used to set the ROI in functions that require it. Ignores the file's EXIF rotation data.

docs.title: Output File
docs.text: The path to save the operation's output.

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text: The user can choose between AVI, TIFF or MP4.

docs.title: Output Image
docs.text: The path to save the operation's image output. Tiff is the recommended format, although all formats supported by OpenCV imwrite are supported.

docs.title: Preview
docs.text: Shows a preview of the function, using the first 10 frames ahead of the Start frame set by the user.

docs.title: Source Video
docs.text: The source video used for tracking. Ideally not the processed one, so you can set the ROIs better.

docs.title: Start and End frame
docs.text:
Specify the frame number to begin and end the processing.

The selection is inclusive, meaning both the start and end frames will be processed.

Frame numbers are one-indexed (the first frame has a frame number equal to 1).

To process the video all the way to its final frame, enter 0 in the 'End frame' field.

docs.title: Check Dependencies
docs.text:
Used during the installation procedure. Needs to be run many (usually three) times after resetting ImageJ to finish the installation.

Installs FFmpeg and OpenCV jars using another plugin, JavaCVInstaller.

docs.title: Create Sequential ROIs
docs.text:
Creates circular ROIs according to the number and size specified by the user. Positions them according to a grid (the smallest divisors to the chosen number of wells). The size unit will rely on the scale previously stated. All ROIs are added to the ROI manager.

Changing their position consists of:

  1. Clicking on one ROI in the ROI Manager.
  2. Moving the selected ROI around.
  3. Clicking Update in ROI Manager.

Saving these ROIs is recommended, as they are used in many functions and are re-usable.

Saving ROIs

Avoid saving only one ROI instead of the whole collection. Before saving, select all of them in the ROI Manager (using the Shift key).

docs.title: FFmpeg
docs.text: A graphical user interface to use FFmpeg. It's simplified to display only the features used in this plugin's domain.

docs.title: Input Video
docs.text: Any videos supported by ffmpeg. This includes most video formats in existence. Notably, one exclusion: AVI videos saved from ImageJ with compression set to "None" (codec rawvideo) will not work.

docs.title: Open Frame
docs.text: Opens the first frame of the video as a preview. Can be used to set the ROI in functions that require it. Ignores the file's EXIF rotation data.

docs.title: Output File
docs.text: The path to save the operation's output.

docs.title: Output Codec
docs.text: Choose between mjpeg (AVI), libx264 (MP4) and libx265 (MP4 with better compression). ImageJ only can read AVI video files with mjpeg codec, so that's the preferred one.

docs.title: Start and End frame
docs.text:
Specify the frame number to begin and end the processing.

Zero-indexed values

This field behaves differently from all other frame inputs in this plugin. It's zero-indexed, meaning the first frame has a number value of zero.

The selection is inclusive, meaning both the start and end frames will be processed.

To process the video all the way to its final frame, enter 0 in the 'End frame' field.

docs.title: Output FPS
docs.text: Frames per second rate of the output video. The "Open Frame & Get Info" button above autofills this field with the input file's frame rate.

docs.title: Horizontal Flip
docs.text: Flips the video horizontally. Based on the Preview's frame position. Uses a ffmpeg fiter.

docs.title: Vertical Flip
docs.text: Flips the video vertically. Based on the Preview's frame position. Uses a ffmpeg fiter.

docs.title: Rotation
docs.text: Rotates the video by the set degrees amount. Based on the Preview's frame position. Uses a ffmpeg fiter.

docs.title: Crop Using Active ROI
docs.text: Crops the video using the active ROI in the preview image. If not found, uses the selected one in ROI Manager. If not found, uses the first one in ROIManger.

docs.title: Multi-Crop
docs.text: Creates one video for every ROI in ROI Manager. To be saved in the folder of the output file, with each ROI name appended to the file name.

docs.title: Preview
docs.text: Process one frame of the input file with the selected options and displays it. Useful for making sure the rotation and crop filters are working as expected.

docs.title: Image Calculator
docs.text: Performs a mathematical operation on a video and an image. Similar to ImageJ's built-in one (without the need to load the video to RAM).

docs.title: Input Video
docs.text: Any videos supported by ffmpeg. This includes most video formats in existence. Notably, one exclusion: AVI videos saved from ImageJ with compression set to "None" (codec rawvideo) will not work.

docs.title: Open Frame
docs.text: Opens the first frame of the video as a preview. Can be used to set the ROI in functions that require it. Ignores the file's EXIF rotation data.

docs.title: Input Image
docs.text:
Image to perform the operation. Any image format supported by OpenCV's imread can be used.

Image and Video Mismatch

This image and the input video need to be in the same resolution, bit depth and channel count.

It's recommended to only use images generated from this plugin's Z-Project function.

Notably, 32-bit images aren't supported.

docs.title: Output File
docs.text: The path to save the operation's output.

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text: The user can choose between AVI, TIFF or MP4.

docs.title: Save Output
docs.text: Choose whether to save the output to the specified output path. If left unchecked, only displays the output.

docs.title: Invert before operation
docs.text: Invert each frame before performing the operation. Done as a bitwise NOT operation.

docs.title: Operation
docs.text: Mathematical operation to be performed on the inputs. Same effect as the built-in ImageJ ones.

docs.title: Start and End frame
docs.text:
Specify the frame number to begin and end the processing.

The selection is inclusive, meaning both the start and end frames will be processed.

Frame numbers are one-indexed (the first frame has a frame number equal to 1).

To process the video all the way to its final frame, enter 0 in the 'End frame' field.

docs.title: Preview
docs.text: Shows a preview of the function, using the first 10 frames ahead of the Start frame set by the user.

docs.title: Invert Video
docs.text: Uses OpenCV and FFmpeg to invert each frame, allowing faster operation without the need to load the whole video into memory. Done as a bitwise NOT operation.

docs.title: Input Video
docs.text: Any videos supported by ffmpeg. This includes most video formats in existence. Notably, one exclusion: AVI videos saved from ImageJ with compression set to "None" (codec rawvideo) will not work.

docs.title: Open Frame
docs.text: Opens the first frame of the video as a preview. Can be used to set the ROI in functions that require it. Ignores the file's EXIF rotation data.

docs.title: Output Image
docs.text: The path to save the operation's image output. Tiff is the recommended format, although all formats supported by OpenCV imwrite are supported.

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text: The user can choose between AVI, TIFF or MP4.

docs.title: Save Output
docs.text: Choose whether to save the output to the specified output path. If left unchecked, only displays the output.

docs.title: Start and End frame
docs.text:
Specify the frame number to begin and end the processing.

The selection is inclusive, meaning both the start and end frames will be processed.

Frame numbers are one-indexed (the first frame has a frame number equal to 1).

To process the video all the way to its final frame, enter 0 in the 'End frame' field.

docs.title: Preview
docs.text: Shows a preview of the function, using the first 10 frames ahead of the Start frame set by the user.

docs.title: Performance Test
docs.text:
Used to test the plugin's performance. Creates a video with the specified dimensions and length set to the product of them.

Each video frame has one more white pixel than the last one. Pixels are filled in left to right and up to bottom.

Avoid Big Dimensions

Only use small resolutions. Even using a relatively low resolution such as VGA (800x600) will create a video with 480,000 frames. That's a 4,5 hour-long AVI video, at 30 fps, saved with low compression. This will use A LOT of HDD space. And, most importantly, it won't fit in your computer's RAM to be processed by ImageJ's built-in Z-project function.

The video is saved as a temp file; then the operation Z-Project (Max intensity) is run, both with the ImageJ's built-in tool and this plugin's implementation.

The time to complete these operations is displayed.

docs.title: Input Video
docs.text: Any videos supported by ffmpeg. This includes most video formats in existence. Notably, one exclusion: AVI videos saved from ImageJ with compression set to "None" (codec rawvideo) will not work.

docs.title: Open Frame
docs.text: Opens the first frame of the video as a preview. Can be used to set the ROI in functions that require it. Ignores the file's EXIF rotation data.

docs.title: Output Image
docs.text: The path to save the operation's image output. Tiff is the recommended format, although all formats supported by OpenCV imwrite are supported.

docs.title: Save Output
docs.text: Choose whether to save the output to the specified output path. If left unchecked, only displays the output.

docs.title: Invert before operation
docs.text: Invert each frame before performing the operation. Done as a bitwise NOT operation.

docs.title: Processing Mode
docs.text:
The operations available mimic ImageJ's built-in Image → Stacks → Z project operations:

  • Darkest (Min)
  • Brightest (Max)
  • Average
  • Sum (saved as 32-bit)

docs.title: Start and End frame
docs.text:
Specify the frame number to begin and end the processing.

The selection is inclusive, meaning both the start and end frames will be processed.

Frame numbers are one-indexed (the first frame has a frame number equal to 1).

To process the video all the way to its final frame, enter 0 in the 'End frame' field.

docs.title: Preview
docs.text: Shows a preview of the function, using the first 10 frames ahead of the Start frame set by the user.
